row.cell: Survey design and technical documentation supporting the 2021 OECD Survey on Drivers of Trust in Government Institutions (en)

Official Development Assistance by regime context (2010-19) (en)
Fighting climate change: International attitudes toward climate policies (en)
Does the digital world open up an increasing divide in access to print books? (en)
In most countries, people with low income tend to trust the government less (en)
Share of respondents who indicate trust in the national government (responses 6-10 on an 11‑point scale), by net disposable household income, 2021 (en)
Reliability and fairness have a significant relationship with trust in the civil service (en)

Percentage point change in trust in civil service in response to improvements in selected variables (left Y-axis, represented by bar) and OECD unweighted average respondents' satisfaction in the noted variables (right Y-axis, represented by dot) (en)
Trust in other people and the police is relatively high, while political parties are viewed with scepticism (en)
Share of respondents who report that they trust a given group or institution, unweighted OECD average, 2021 (en)
Socioeconomic conditions and political attitudes: Microfoundations of trust (en)
Four in ten say they trust business conditions that government can influence to remain stable (en)

Share of respondents reporting different levels of perceived likelihood that business conditions that government can influence will be stable and predictable (on a 0-10 scale), unweighted OECD average, 2021 (en)
Openness, integrity and equal treatment: Critical for trust and for democracy (en)
Perception that information is easily available is positively linked with satisfaction with administrative services cross-nationally (en)

Share of respondents who consider it likely that information about administrative procedures would be easily available and share of respondents who are satisfied with the quality of administrative services, 2021 (en)
About half say their government would be prepared for the next pandemic (en)

Share of respondents reporting different levels of perceived likelihood that their government would be prepared to protect people's lives in the event of a new serious contagious illness (on a 0-10 scale), 2021 (en)
Main Findings from the 2021 OECD Survey on Drivers of Trust in Public Institutions (en)
Perceptions of economic vulnerability influence expectations of (un)equal treatment by government employees (en)

Share of respondents who indicate different levels of perceived likelihood that a government employee would treat rich and poor equally, presented separately for those who are concerned and not concerned about their household's finances (on a 0-10 scale), 2021 (en)
People with personal financial concerns are less likely to trust the government (en)
Share of respondents who indicate trust in the national government (responses 6-10 on an 11‑point scale) by level of respondents’ personal financial concerns, 2021 (en)
Lower levels of perceived corruption among public employees are associated with higher levels of trust in national government cross-nationally (en)
Share of respondents reporting trust in national government (on a 0-10 scale), and share of respondents who consider it likely that a public employee would refuse a bribe (on a 0-10 scale), 2021 (en)

Half of respondents think their government should prioritise actions to reduce climate change, but only about one-third have confidence in their country’s ability to reduce greenhouse gas emissions (en)

Share of respondents who say government should prioritise reducing country’s contribution to climate change and share of respondents who have confidence in their country’s ability to reduce greenhouse gas emissions, 2021 (en)
Instaurer la confiance pour renforcer la démocratie (fr)
Principales conclusions de l’enquête 2021 de l’OCDE sur les déterminants de la confiance dans les institutions publiques (fr)
Most people do not think national policies adapt to public views (en)
Share of respondents reporting different levels of perceived likelihood that a national policy would be changed if a majority of people expressed a view against it (on a 0-10 scale), 2021 (en)
Half of respondents say the political system does not let them have a say in government decision making (en)
Share of respondents reporting different levels of confidence that the political system lets them have a say in government decision making (0-10 scale), 2021 (en)
Trust in government shows large regional disparities within OECD countries (en)
Share of respondents who indicate trust in the national government (responses 6-10 on an 11‑point scale) in regions with highest and lowest level of trust by country, 2021 (en)
A majority feels they can easily find information about administrative procedures (en)
Share of respondents who indicate different levels of the likelihood that they could easily find information about administrative procedures (on a 0-10 scale), OECD unweighted average, 2021 (en)
Main Findings from the 2021 OECD Survey on Drivers of Trust in Public Institutions (en)
Reliable and responsive: Government competence and trust (en)
In most countries, a majority feels they can easily find information about administrative procedures (en)
Share of respondents who indicate different levels of perception of the ease of finding information about administrative procedures (on a 0-10 scale), 2021 (en)
Trust in government is strongly associated with perceptions whether the government would adopt opinions expressed in a public consultation (en)
Share of respondents who trust the national government by whether they are confident or sceptical that governments would adopt opinions gathered via public consultations, 2021 (en)
The way forward: Reinforcing democracy and trust in democratic governance (en)
Older people are much more likely to vote in national elections (en)
Share of respondents who reported having voted in the last national election, by age group, 2021 (en)
Main Findings from the 2021 OECD Survey on Drivers of Trust in Public Institutions (en)
Nearly six out of ten, across countries, are satisfied with the educational system in their country (en)
Within-country distribution of levels of satisfaction with the educational system, 2021 (en)
A minority of respondents say a public service would be improved if people complained (en)
Share of respondents reporting different levels of perceived likelihood that a poorly-performing public service would be improved if many people complained about it (on a 0-10 scale), 2021 (en)
Almost half of respondents predict that a high-level political official would grant a political favour in exchange for the offer of a well-paid private sector job (en)

Share of respondents who indicate that an elected or appointed official would accept or refuse the offer of a well-paid private sector job in exchange for a political favour (on a 0-10 scale), unweighted OECD average, 2021 (en)
Confidence in own ability to participate in politics matters for whether people feel like they can voice views on local government decisions (en)
Share of people who feel they would be able to voice their views about a local government decision by level of confidence in own ability to participate in politics (en)
Younger people tend to have lower trust in government (en)
Share of respondents who indicate trust the national government (responses 6-10 on an 11‑point scale) by age group, 2021 (en)
The way forward: Reinforcing democracy and trust in democratic governance (en)
Instaurer la confiance pour renforcer la démocratie (fr)
Principales conclusions de l’enquête 2021 de l’OCDE sur les déterminants de la confiance dans les institutions publiques (fr)
Trust in government is strongly associated with whether people can easily access information (en)
Share of respondents who trust the national government by whether they think it is likely or not that information on administrative processes is easily available (on a 0-10 scale), 2021 (en)
Countries that are seen as more competent in the fight against climate change also benefit from higher levels of trust in government (en)

Share of respondents that are confident that their country will succeed in reducing greenhouse gas emissions over the next 10 years (x-axis) and the share who trust their national government (y-axis), 2021 (en)
Measuring trust in government to reinforce democracy (en)
Trust in government is lower for people that did not vote for parties in power (en)

Share of respondents reporting they trust the national government (responses 6-10 on an 11‑point scale) by whether they voted for the party/parties in power in the previous national election, 2021 (en)
Openness, integrity and equal treatment: Critical for trust and for democracy (en)
Half of respondents, on average, trust their government to use their personal data for legitimate purposes (en)
Share of respondents reporting different levels of perceived likelihood that their government would use personal data exclusively for “legitimate purposes” (on a 0-10 scale), 2021 (en)
Very few think that the government would adopt views expressed in a public consultation (en)
Share of respondents who indicate different levels of perceived likelihood that a government would adopt opinions expressed in a public consultation (on a 0-10 scale), 2021 (en)
Just over four in ten people trust their national government (en)
Share of respondents who indicate different levels of trust in their national government (on a 0-10 scale), 2021 (en)
Higher trust in government may influence preferences for governments to do more (en)

Percent of respondents that want their government to prioritise specific policy issues more (as opposed to “About the same” or “Less”), by their level of trust in national government, unweighted OECD average, 2021 (en)
Measuring trust in government to reinforce democracy (en)
Only four out of ten respondents believe judiciaries make decisions free of political influence (en)
Share of respondents who indicate different levels of perceived likelihood that a court would make a decision that could negatively affect the government’s image (on a 0-10 scale), 2021 (en)
Reliable and responsive: Government competence and trust (en)
Only four in ten think that a public employee would treat rich and poor people equally (en)
Share of respondents who indicate different levels of perceived likelihood that a public employee would treat both rich and poor people equally (on a 0-10 scale), 2021 (en)
Instaurer la confiance pour renforcer la démocratie (fr)
Principales conclusions de l’enquête 2021 de l’OCDE sur les déterminants de la confiance dans les institutions publiques (fr)
Television, newspapers and social media are the most common news sources (en)
Share of respondents selecting each of the following medium as a weekly source of information about politics and current events, 2021 (en)
Respondents most likely to support global co‑operation to resolve challenges like climate change, terrorism and pandemic preparation (en)
Share of respondents picking each of the following options as one of their top priorities for global co‑operation, unweighted OECD average, 2021 (en)
Public trust in the police, courts and legal system is generally high (en)
Share of respondents who indicate trust in various institutions (responses 6-10 on a 10-point scale), 2021 (en)
Very few think that their government would adopt opinions expressed in a public consultation (en)
Share of respondents who indicate different levels of perceived likelihood that a government would adopt opinions expressed in a public consultation (on a 0-10 scale), 2021 (en)
In most OECD countries women have lower trust in the national government than men (en)
Difference in trust in government by gender, expressed as the share of men trusting government minus the share of women trusting government, in percentage points, 2021 (en)
Younger people are more likely to want action on climate change as a policy priority (en)

Difference between the percentage of young (18- to 29-year-olds) respondents who want their government to “do more” to reduce their country's contribution to climate change minus the percentage of older (age 50 and over) respondents who want more action to reduce climate change, expressed in percentage points, 2021 (en)
Socioeconomic conditions and political attitudes: Microfoundations of trust (en)
Over one-third find it likely that a public employee would accept a bribe (en)
Share of respondents who indicate that a public employee would accept or refuse a bribe (on a 0-10 scale), 2021 (en)
Trust in political parties, national legislatures and the media is low throughout the OECD (en)
Share of respondents who indicate trust in various institutions (responses 6-10 on a 10-point scale), 2021 (en)
The public has a lack of confidence in public agencies adopting innovative ideas (en)
Share of respondents reporting different levels of perceived likelihood that a public agency/office would adopt an innovative idea that could improve a public service (on a 0-10 scale), 2021 (en)
People with a low self-reported social status have also lower trust in government (en)
Share of respondents who indicate trust in the national government (responses 6-10 on an 11‑point scale) among people with higher and lower perceived social status, 2021 (en)
Main Findings from the 2021 OECD Survey on Drivers of Trust in Public Institutions (en)
People with tertiary education tend to have higher trust in government (en)
Share of respondents who indicate trust in the national government (responses 6-10 on an 11‑point scale) by highest level of education, 2021 (en)
Trust in government correlates with trust in other people (en)
Share of people in OECD countries that trust the national government (y-axis) by share that trust other people (x-axis) (both responses 6-10 on an 11‑point scale), 2021 (en)
People who feel they have a say in what the government does have also higher trust in government (en)
Share of respondents reporting they trust the national government (responses 6-10 on an 1-point scale) by whether they feel they have a say in what the government does, 2021 (en)
People generally trust their civil service and local government more than their national government (en)
Share of respondents who indicate trust in various government institutions (responses 6-10 on a 10-point scale), 2021 (en)
Reliability and feelings of political voice are significantly related to trust in national government (en)

Percentage point change in trust in national government in response to improvements in selected variables (left Y-axis, represented by bar) and OECD unweighted average respondents' satisfaction in the noted variables (right Y-axis, represented by dot), 2021 (en)
Openness and reliability are significantly associated with trust in local government (en)

Percentage point change in trust in local government in response to improvements in selected variables (left Y-axis, represented by bar) and OECD unweighted average respondents' confidence in the noted variables (right Y-axis, represented by dot) (en)
Governments fare better on measures of reliability than on responsiveness (en)
Share of respondents expressing confidence in government reliability, responsiveness, openness, integrity, and fairness (average across survey questions), unweighted OECD average, 2021 (en)
Trust in the courts and legal system is positively associated with perceptions of independence of the courts (en)

Share of respondents who believe a court in their country would make a decision free from political influence (y-axis) and share of respondents who trust the courts and legal system (x-axis), 2021 (en)
A majority of respondents, across countries, are satisfied with the provision of healthcare (en)
Share of respondents reporting different levels of satisfaction with the healthcare system in their country (on a 0-10 scale), 2021 (en)
Instaurer la confiance pour renforcer la démocratie (fr)
Principales conclusions de l’enquête 2021 de l’OCDE sur les déterminants de la confiance dans les institutions publiques (fr)
Few people feel they would be able to voice their views about a local government decision affecting their community (en)

Share of respondents who indicate different levels of perceived likelihood that they would have the opportunity to voice their views if a local government decision affects their community (on a 0-10 scale), 2021 (en)
Higher confidence that a government agency would adopt innovative ideas is associated with higher trust in civil servants (en)
Share of respondents who report they trust the civil service, sorted by their perception that a government agency would or would not adopt an innovative idea, 2021 (en)
Newspaper readership is slightly more positively correlated with trust in government than news from social media (en)

Share of respondents trusting the national government vis-à-vis the share obtaining news at least once a week from newspapers (including online newspapers) (Panel A) and the share obtaining news at least once a week from social media (Panel B), 2021 (en)
The majority of respondents expect that their application for a government benefit or service would be treated fairly (en)
Share of respondents who indicate different levels of perceived likelihood that a government would treat their application for a government benefit or service fairly (on a 0-10 scale), 2021 (en)
Positive perceptions of preparedness for a future pandemic are associated with higher trust in the national government – and vice versa (en)

Share of respondents reporting trust in national government and share of respondents who consider it likely that government institutions will be prepared to protect people's lives in the event of a future pandemic, 2021 (en)
